Name: Záhadné Případy
Description:
Is the killer really a gardener again? Did Filip Mazaný rob Mrs. Sad or was it Lukáš Lapka?

Will you solve these mysterious cases together with Inspector ÄŒmuchal? Mainly pay attention to details, they often tell you!
The game contains 54 cases including their solution and rules in the Czech language.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Do you like to solve various puzzles, quizzes and mysteries?  Brain game - Mysterious cases perfectly practice your brain threads!  Make sure you are smart enough to outsmart your opponents.  But beware - it's not as easy a task as it may seem.  The mysteries of this fun game are so rolled out that they really can't sleep!
 The aim of the game is to correctly solve the intricate mysterious cases, whose text is written on the cards.  If the answer is correct, the player keeps this card, otherwise he returns it.  The player who first solves five puzzles correctly, thus collecting five cards, wins and can enjoy the deserved victory.  The game develops logical thinking and patience and is suitable for children from the age of ten.

—user summary

Je vrahem opravdu opÄ›t zahradník? Okradl Filip Mazaný paní Smutnou nebo to byl Lukáš Lapka?

VyÅ™ešíte spoleÄnÄ› s inspektorem ÄŒmuchalem tyto záhadné pÅ™ípady? HlavnÄ› si všímejte detailÅ¯, ty vám mnohdy napoví!
Hra obsahuje 54 pÅ™ípadÅ¯ vÄetnÄ› jejich Å™ešení a pravidla v Äeském jazyce.

—description from the publisher

Name: Go Get Fish
Description:
GoGetFish is the fishing game for 2-4 players.

GAME OBJECTIVE
Each player assumes the role of a skillful fisherman, who came from around the world to compete for the championship in fishing. Whenever your turn comes up, you may move your ship and select one of the following 4 action options:

     Fishing
     Collect treasure chest
     Docking
     Pass


The first player who was able to acquire 12 trophy points or the player who collected all of the 3 Artifacts will be the winner.

—description from the designer

Name: Logical Curling
Description:
Logical Curling is an abstract game that simulates the game of Curling. Players roll and reroll dice, to try and obtain specific patterns, similar to poker hands, which determine the movement of stones. The higher scoring patterns give players access to more powerful and flexible trajectories - but there are rules that prevent the game from becoming a luck fest.

The stones have to enter the board and slide according to specific, somewhat limited curved trajectories, and they can bump and dislodge other stones already on the board. So, when deciding which dice to reroll, players have to take into consideration not only the numbers they already have, but also the current board state, and what trajectories might become available with those numbers.

The player or team that manages to get their stones closest to the target, and bump the opponent's stones away, scores for the round. The player or team with the highest score after 6, 8 or 10 rounds is the winner!

The game can also be played with a standard deck of cards instead of dice. According to the designer, this variant is more difficult, but also more subtle and interesting.

—description from the designer

Name: Choirs Are Horrible
Description:
Because as awesome as choir is, it's also kind of horrible.

Bass notes you can only hit during allergy season. Illegal photocopies of music. Singing with so much phlegm your throat is like a flute filled with gravy. Celebrate all the things that make choir special in this hilarious and snarky card game for die-hard choir geeks! Designed to be high school appropriate, your students will stay in the choir room to play this game, instead of doing drugs. It's that good, and you might save a life.

—description from the publisher

Name: Orchestras Are Awful
Description:
Dead strings. Bridge collapse. Suzuki Book 3. Not enough rosin. There are so many orchestral annoyances that make this otherwise awesome activity absolutely awful. But it's okay, because now you can vent about them all with your friends, and then get back to playing Nimrod or Hoedown whatever your favorite piece is at the moment. Play Orchestras Are Awful, the newest card game from Truly Horrible Things. It's much cheaper than therapy.
â€‹
This game was written by violinists, primarily, so you immediately know two things: their goal was perfection, and they are certain they achieved it. It is meant to be enjoyed by high school orchestra students, but will be enjoyed even more by their directors. Get a few sets to keep the kids occupied when they are hanging out in the orchestra room before school. You've got stuff to do.

—description from the publisher

Name: Theatre Is Tragic
Description:
Ok theater kids...we heard you. A smelly costume. Unblended make up. Being tricked into naming the Scottish play. So many things about the thing we love are terrible things. So hey, why not play cards?


     396 cards
     high school appropriate
     Ages 14+
     Perfect for classrooms, cast parties, tech rehearsals, and any time you should be working on lines.


—description from the publisher

Name: Trivial Pursuit: The Shakespeare Edition
Description:
Exclusively produced for The Shakespeare Birthplace Trust, this exciting new edition has 600 questions based on the life and the works of William Shakespeare.

This handy game requires no board, can be played on the go, as a card game, carried in its bite-size wedge case or can be added to your existing Trivial Pursuit board game, with its own spare wedge holder.

Test your trivia with the following topics: Comedies, Histories, Tragedies, Characters, Biography and Legacy.

Name: Secret Hunters
Description:
Mega City a Moloch of a city was flashy, loud and dirty. Life was hard and survival was complicated. If you knew the right people in Mega City it was easier. If you did what you were told, it was also easy. But the easiest way was to simply not stand out, become invisible, merge with the haze of the city and stay out of everything. What do I care? That’s the way it is. Many of the young people didn't mind, they were just interested in having fun, being cool and being able to do what they wanted to do. Why should one then interfere with the stress that the old people made for themselves. Until, yes, until you faced reality, staring at you brutally and cruelly, punching you in the face, breaking your bones or snuffing out your lights. 
That reality was a man whom everybody only referred to as ”The Baron”, the crime lord who controlled everything in Mega City. His army of henchmen was everywhere and enforced his will with unlimited brutality and cruelty. 
In Secret Hunters, each player leads a group of young people who have formed a gang with the goal of overthrowing The Baron. They all share the fate of having been brutally abused by The Baron and his henchmen. To achieve their goal are not choosy with their methods. They hack terminals, crack safes, bribe the followers of the mystery man, but they would never use weapons. Each gang consists of 4 specialists. A hacker, a safecracker, a spy and a biker. Using the action board and 4 action tokens, the characters are guided through Mega City, but, The Baron does not just watch as his weaknesses uncovered, his henchmen strike mercilessly. Four pieces of evidence need to be found and presented to the court in order to take out The Baron, but to find out which four pieces of evidence they are, the players need to collect clues they get from informants, as to where relevant safes and terminals are located which may contain possible evidence. The gang which has collected all four pieces of evidence and manages to take them to court wins the game and is referred to by the others as the real Secret Hunters.

—description from the designer

Name: Starving Artists: 5-6 Player Expansion
Description: Expansion includes player references, player tokens, and rule changes sheet to increase the game of Starving Artists up to 6 players.

Name: Starving Artists: Sketch & Study Expansion
Description:
The first "new game mechanism" expansion for Starving Artists from the 2019 Kickstarter:

These cards would be worth no food or points and don't count toward a canvas victory. However, when you complete the card, you can "sell" it (as your free action for the day) and take five paints from the bag of your choice. Not a random pull.

These cards would be available to all players to take instead of a normal buy action. They cost nothing to take, but there's a limited number of them and you can only have one at a time.

They are painted using five of any paint cubes like any other normal paint action.

What this solves

This new Sketch and Study option means:

Players have a better way to convert unwanted/unneeded paints; 
Players can use the sketches to better utilize their painting actions (e.g., if you only need to paint once or twice to finish a canvas); and 
While they last, there's always something "to buy" regardless of how much paint you have and regardless if the market doesn't have a great set for you personally.

Name: Starving Artists: 2017 Kickstarter Art Packs
Description:
Stretch goal art packs from the 2017 Kickstarter:
 'Science Art' - Adds 8 science-themed canvases from NASA, John Audubon, & others
 'Around the World' - Adds 8 new canvases featuring locations around the world
 'Comic & Pop' Art - Adds 8 new canvases featuring pulp comic, illustrations, and pop art.
 'Split Squares' - Adds 8 new canvases with split color squares

Name: Starving Artists: 2019 Kickstarter Art Packs
Description:
Stretch goal art packs from the 2019 Kickstarter:
'Surrealism' - Adds 3 new canvases from Alice Bailly, Morton Shamberg and Max Ernst
'Impressionism' - Adds 3 new canvases from Claude Monet, Mary Cassatt and Edgar Degas
'Abstract' - Adds 3 abstract/futurism canvases from Giacomo Balla, Frantisek Kupka and Benedetta Cappa
'Asia Art' - Adds 3 new canvases from Korea, Japan and China
'Welcome Back Pack' - Adds the 6 cards that didn't make the cut during the first Kickstarter campaign
'Crystallo Creatures' - Adds 6 cards to celebrate the Kickstarter campaign of solo game Crystallo

As well as 3 additional backer chosen cards

Name: Air Combat: Rules for Wargames
Description: Air Combat are rules for miniature wargames.

Name: Rules for Wargames: The American Civil War
Description: Miniature wargame rules

Name: Rules for Wargames: World War II – Infantry Combat
Description: Miniature wargame rules

Name: Microtank Warfare
Description: Miniature wargame rules for 1/300 scale figures.

Name: Rules for Wargames: The Colonial Wars
Description: Miniature Wargame Rules

Name: The Pursuit of Happiness: Order From Artipia
Description:
Order From Artipia promo card is an additional Standard Project that can be added to the base game.

It is given out via orders from the Artipia Games online store.

Name: Devil's Chess
Description:
Devil's Chess is a deck of cards that compliments traditional chess.  It is easy to learn, infinitely re-playable, and is wildly addictive.  Devil's Chess brings modern board game mechanics to an old classic.  With Devil's Chess you get a bit of randomness, new mechanics and card combos, and a whole lot of new tricks to surprise your opponent. Devil's Chess brings Chess out of the 6th century and into the 21st!

Setting up the game is easy.  Shuffle both decks, and set them to the left and right of the chessboard.  Each player is dealt a hand of three Playable Cards. To begin the game flip over one Rule Card.  Players then take turns playing cards and moving pieces.  When a player draws a “Devil’s Chess” card, another new Rule Card is flipped over.


     At the beginning of your turn, draw a Playable card if you do not have three
     You may use or discard one Playable Card
     Your turn ends after you move a chess piece


The game is over when a King is put into checkmate or when a “More Ways to Win!” condition is met by a player.

With 30 unique Rule Cards and 90 Playable Cards, Devil’s Chess is unbelievably re-playable.  We know you’ll make it a mainstay in your game library.

—description from the publisher

Name: Zombies!!!: Vegas Kickstarter Promotional Cards
Description: A set of 10 promotional event cards generated during the Zombies!!!: Vegas Kickstarter campaign (March 2020).

Name: Let Me Off
Description:
The trick-taking game Let Me Off was one of the finalists in the 2017 Trick Taking Party design competition in Japan, and Taiki Shinzawa, one of the judges, selected it as his personal award.

In the game, players each have 3 hands of cards.  Each player has one hand to themselves that they hold, but 2 additional hands, one on each side, that is held in a card rack and shared with their neighbor.

Players may only follow suit, and if they cannot follow suit from any of their hands, they do not play a card at all. A round ends when one player has no cards left in any of their hands.  Any person who has played all of the cards from each of their hands earns 1 point per trick won.  All players lose 1 point per card left in each of their hands as well as losing a variable number of points based upon aces collected in tricks.

After several rounds, the player with the most points wins.

Name: Das Adam Riese Spiel
Description:
Arithmetic game for 1, 2 or any number of people

In addition to the basic form - BINGOLETTE - the game contains six other rules. In the basic form, the aim is to achieve a number between 1 and 36 with the three dice rolled using any arithmetic operation (adding, subtracting, multiplying, dividing, exponentiating or rooting). This is then covered on the game board and the player receives the points according to the number on the edge. When all game board spaces are covered, the player with the highest total points wins. The six other rules of the game are: 1. Raffkes Los, 2. Holzauktion, 3. Stall fürs Pferd, 4. Graben und Brücke, 5. Gewinn-Mühle, 6. Der Rechenmeister.

—user summary

Name: Black Squares
Description: Designed by Harry Wollerton and refined by David Parlett, Black Squares is a pencil-and-paper (and pen-and-eraser) word game in which two players are filling in a crossword grid. However, players don't score points by creating words; they score points by identifying the locations of black squares.

Name: シェリフ (Sheriff)
Description:
In the trick-taking game ã‚·ã‚§ãƒªãƒ• (Sheriff), designed for exactly 3 players, one player takes on the role of the Sheriff, another the Robber, and the last the Mayor.

Each role will score points differently.  The Sheriff scores 1 point for each King taken in a trick.  The Robber scores 1 point for each 10 taken in a trick.  The Mayor, who decides on the trump suit, receives 1 point for each Queen and Jack collected; loses 1 point for each King the Sheriff does not win; and loses 1 point for each 10 the Robber does collect.

Play continues over several rounds until one player has earned 8 points.  The player with the highest score wins.

Name: DATTO!
Description:
DATTO! is a trick-taking game based on the fable of the Hare & the Tortoise. It is ostensibly a race game, in which the player to advance the farthest will win.

Turn order for each trick is based upon the players' position in the race, with the players who have advanced the least playing cards to each trick first. Players must follow suit if possible, and the winner will advance a number of spaces equal to the lowest value played in the lead suit. If only one card of the lead suit is played, the player advances a number of spaces equal to the number of cards left in their hand.

Each player also receives a "nap" card, which allows them to sit out of one trick.
Families: Folk Tales & Fairy Tales: The Tortoise and the Hare

Name: 新幕 桜降る代に決闘を 第参拡張：零限突破 (A Duel for Falling Cherry Blossoms: New Act – 3rd Expansion – Breakthrough Zero)
Description: Expansion including two new megami to the story, Cornu and Yatsuha.

Name: Longships: The Wrath of the Vikings – Raids and Battles in the Ninth Century
Description:
These rules use a lot of new mechanisms. Each player has about 6 units, In a fight a unit would typically shieldwall, issue challenges, advance to contact whilst sending in line breakers. The fight might break the shield walls kill the men etc...

This is a historical set, which requires the player to play historically rather than giving the players what they like and then writing rules around that.

—description from the publisher

Name: 新幕 桜降る代に決闘を 第四拡張：大洋航路 (A Duel for Falling Cherry Blossoms: New Act – 4th expansion – Ocean Route)
Description: An expansion adding two new megami to the story, Hatsumi and Mizuki!

Name: Wars of the Roses: The Bloody Barons
Description:
It is completely different to the first edition of Bloody Barons.  
It does share the same basing system and army size so that players of BB1 can use BB2 whenever they wish.

As usual there are many new ideas not seen before in gaming rules.

—description from the publisher

Name: Western: Battles in the Old West 1830-85
Description:
Western rules that cover the battles of the Old West.

These replace the 1992 Hey you in the Jail set. We usually update rules after about 10 years.
These rules are  designed for games wherein the figures operate in groups. They are not a skirmish set .

WESTERN is an historical game (the word "faction" is not used)
There are ten force options (Mexicans, Plains Indians, townsfolk, posse, Gunmen, army, workers, cattlemen....).

A typical force in 15mm would use 100 figures (about 50 in 25mm) put into 5 groups. 
5 x 3 table. 
All mechanisms uses the table grid (6 inch squares for 15mm, 8" for 25mm etc).

The rules will use the usual wire bound "lay flat" PP style.
The signature PP grid system is also used. Western is full of new ideas and elegant processes.

As usual the play sheets and battle sheet swill be "down loadable" free of charge on the PP website.

Name: Vietnam: The Men of Company B – Wargame Rules for Vietnam 1955-1975
Description:
The Men of Company B (MCB) covers search and destroy actions in Vietnam at platoon level.

The figure scale is 1:1.  
Each player controls about 50 figures.

There is also the ability to include vehicles.

The US or allied player searches and the communist player attempts to stop him.

MCB uses a terrain map made from grid squares so no measuring is needed making the game faster.

Name: PBI: Company Commander Edition – A Game of WW2 Company Combat
Description:
PBI (Poor Bloody Infantry) is a Miniatures wargame ruleset for WW2 company level gaming.

For 10 to 25 mm miniatures.

PBI is designed to allow fast playing games that finish in a couple of hours.

PBI uses a terrain map made from grid squares (6") so no measuring is needed.

It is a complete game system, including:

     scenario generator,
     points,
     victory schedule.


—description from the publisher
Families: Series: Poor Bloody Infantry – WWII Miniature Rules (Peter Pig)

Name: Commands & Colors: Napoleonics Expansion 7 – The Grand Battles
Description:
The Commands & Colors: Napoleonics game system allows players to effectively portray Napoleonic "Grand" size battles, as well as smaller historical actions. The scale of the game is flexible and varies from battle to battle. In some scenarios, a unit may represent an entire division, while in others, a unit may represent a single regiment or battalion. During play, the Command cards drive movement, while creating a “fog of war”, and the battle dice resolve combat quickly and efficiently. The stylized battlefield maps emphasize the important terrain features and highlight the historical deployment of forces in scale with the game system. Finally, the Napoleonic tactics you will need to execute to gain victory conform remarkably well to the advantages and limitations inherent to the various Napoleonic national armies of the day and the actual battlefield terrain features on which they fought.

The Grand Battles is the seventh expansion for GMT’s Commands & Colors: Napoleonics game system. The expansion features as many as 10 Grand Battle scenarios, 10 EPIC engagements, and a number of standard-sized battles. The Grand Battles battlefield is a whopping 11 hexes deep by 26 hexes wide, and there are two Grand Battles mounted map boards (left and right) included in the expansion. The EPIC battlefield is 11 hexes deep by 20 hexes wide, which is almost double the size of the standard scenario battlefield of 9 hexes deep by 13 hexes wide. Two EPIC battlefield map sheets (left and right) are also included.

Special Bonus: There are two Grand Battles extended size scenarios on a double-sided preprinted paper map, Waterloo 18 June 1815 and Borodino 7 September 1812. These two battles are 11 hexes deep by 29 hexes wide and because the battlefield is already printed with all the terrain and unit deployments, the time it takes to set up these battles is minimal.
 Players will find a number of new units, including Polish French allies, British highlanders, KGL infantry and cavalry, plus all the unit blocks and rules needed when fielding these units in a battle.

The expansion also includes a number of Leader of Honor blocks. Leader of Honor blocks have a portrait of the Napoleonic leader and were first mentioned in the Generals, Marshals & Tacticians expansion #5. A Leader of Honor orders more units when a “Take Command” Command card is played. Please note, the number of Leader of Honor blocks for the various Napoleonic nations will vary and are determined in scale with each Napoleonic Army’s field commander status history.
 This expansion also presents new rules for Iconic Commanders that are recommended for all EPIC and Grand Battle scenarios. For example: When Napoleon is in command, because of his excellent grasp and flow of a battle, after the play of a Scout Command card, the French player, when drawing two new Command cards, can keep both cards and discard one Command card from his hand. When Wellington is in command, because of his keen eye for terrain, the British player prior to the battle may redeploy up to 4 hexes of units. For example: One unit could redeploy up to 4 hexes or two units 2 hexes each or four units 1 hex each, etc. Other Napoleonic nations also have their own unique Iconic Commander rules.

Knowing that it is not always easy to muster eight players, you will find that a scenario of EPIC Napoleonics will play out very well with just two players. It is highly recommended players give the EPIC scenarios a try, playing one on one. While a Grand Battle game is best played with eight players (four players taking command on each side). The Grand Battles rules found in this expansion, however, have be slightly modified from the Grand Battles rules originally presented in EPIC Napoleonics expansion #6. Basically, we found after playing through these larger battle scenarios a number of times, that the updated rules will allow each player to be more involved and have greater control during the entire battle.
 To experience the maximum enjoyment with these two Napoleonic game formats, both EPIC and Grand Battle scenarios are best played using the Command card and Tactician card decks that were part of the Generals, Marshals & Tacticians expansion.
 It is important to also note in order to play most EPIC Napoleonics scenarios, players will need a copy of the Commands & Colors: Napoleonic core game and many of its expansions (Spanish Army, Russian Army, Austrian Army, Prussian Army, Generals, Marshals & Tacticians, EPIC Napoleonics and The Grand Battles).

Again as I stated previously in the EPIC Napoleonics expansion, it is not the intention of GMT or myself, to require a player to buy multiple copies of the Napoleonic game to play a Grand Battle scenario. I would truly hope, that two friends, both who own copies of the Napoleonic game and expansions could come together with their games, set up a Grand Battles scenario and share in the fun with six more of their friends.
 Although the scope and scale of our Commands & Colors Napoleonic game has increased two fold again, the basic rules of play for the most part, have remained the same. Welcome to the fun!

- Richard Borg

Tentative Component Listing
1 Rule & Scenario Booklet 
2 Grand Battles mounted map boards (left & right)
2 EPIC Battlefield map sheets (left & right)
2 Double-sided Grand Battle Extended Scenario preprinted maps (2 scenarios)
5 Double-sided Grand Battle Scenario cards (10 Grand Battle scenarios)
5 Double-sided EPIC Scenario cards (10 EPIC Battle scenarios)
